subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Lexical sets and QS letters
msgSnippet: ... More like the writing system of Spanish or Czech or Italian or German, only even better.  *Way* better than Polish or French or Swedish or Orthodox
messageBody:
Paul Tremblay scripsit:

> (1) He believes you are a advocating a writing system very similar to
> TO.

More like the writing system of Spanish or Czech or Italian or German,
only even better. *Way* better than Polish or French or Swedish or
Orthodox English.

> That is, you want a standardized (or somewhat standardized?) way of
> spelling words.

Standardized across all dialects that have the same lexical sets,
at least. Slight irregularities will arise from mergers, because
people won't be able to consistently remember which letter represents
which set when they use the same sound for more than one set.

> You also want the writing system to be phonemical, not phonetical.

Indeed, there are no practical orthographies (not counting IPA here;
nobody writes their language in IPA) that are phonetic.

> You want the system to be written in a standardized way that ignores
> dialect, so that someone from America could read someone's writing
> from Australia and understand it easily,

Yes.

> unlike when someone from America heard someone from Australia.

It's easier to understand someone speaking in person than it is to
understand a phonetic transcription of that speech, by a long shot.
All the cues from gesture, tone of voice, context, and so on are lost.

--
